check
Tap the video to watch the steps
1. Stay calm and reassure the patient
2. Let the person take the position he finds most comfortable
3. If the person takes inhaler puffs support him taking his puffs
4. Ensure fresh air by opening the window
5. Assist loosening any tight clothing
6. If the person loss consciousness makes sure the air way stays open
7. Stay with the person and continue to observe him
8. Always refer the person to health care centre for future follow up
9. Always wash your hand after giving care
1, Make sure the area is safe
2, Shout or call for help
3, Use glove or cover with your hands with a plastic bag
4, Ask the person to sit or lay down on the floor
5, Stop bleeding by pressing with both hands on the wound
6, If the bleeding has stopped,cover with a clean cotton cloth
7, Wrap a bandage around the wound
8, Always wash your hand after giving care
1. Make sure the area is safe
2. Call for help
3. If the person cloths are on fire stop the fire
4. Douse the fire
5. Wrap a blanket
6. Ask the victim to roll over
7. Cool the burn with running water for minimum 10 – 15 minutes
8. Do not tear a blister and do not apply any ointment
9. Cover the wound with a clean cotton cloth
10. Keep the victim warm
11. Transport the victim to the nearest healthcare centre
12. Always wash your hand after giving care
1. Make sure the area is safe
2. Shout or call help
3. Ask the person to rest and not move
4. Ask the person to sit down in a comfortable position at a safe location nearby
5. Reassure the person and tell him what is happening
6. Ask the person if he takes medication for his heart condition. If also allow him to take the prescribed medication

7. If there is aspirin available ask if he has any known bleeding disorder or any condition that contradict the usage of aspirin, if none ask the person to chew on an aspirin tablet and swallow it as it will help the blood flow to the heart.
8. Arrange the transport to the nearest healthcare facility
8. Arrange the transport to the nearest healthcare facility
1. Ask the person ‘’are you choking’’
2. If the person answers the question do not do anything else but stay with him and encourage to cough
3. If the person can not speak cough or breath go and stand behind the person
4. Support the person chest with one hand
5. Bend the person forward
6. Give five firms blows between the persons shoulder blades with the help of your hand
7. If the object did not come out stand behind the person
8. Put both arms around the person so your hands meet in front. Make a first place your fist between the person navels and lower tip of his breastbone
9. Bend the person forward
10. Give five abdominal thrusts by pulling your fist inwards and up wards
11. If the object still did not come out then repeat giving five blows and five abdominal thrusts till the object comes outs
12. If the person gets unconscious shout or call for help, lay the person on the floor and start giving CPR
13. Always transport the person to a healthcare for follow up
14. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Shout or call help the baby need urgent help
2. Kneel down on the floor and use your tights to prevent from falling
3. Lay the baby face down on your forearm support the head and neck but make sure the mouth is not covered
4. With your free hand give five blows with the palm of your free hands between the baby shoulder
5. Quickly turn the baby and check if the object came out
6. If the object did n’t come out then place two fingers (do not use your thumbs) in the middle of the baby chest
7. Deliver five thrust by pushing inwards and upwards
8. If the object still did n’t come out then repeat giving five blows and five abdominal thrusts till the object comes outs
9. If the baby is unconscious start giving CPR
10. Always urgent transport the baby to a healthcare centre for follow up
11. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. wash your hands before giving care
2. put on glove if available. You also can use a clean plastic bag to cover your hand
3. stop the bleeding by pressing directly on the wound till the bleeding stops
4. when the bleeding stop rinse the wound with the clean water, if the wound still bleeds do not waste a time to clean the wound but continue to put pressure on the wound to stop the bleeding
5. if you have clean cotton or cloth cover the wound with it
6. apply the bandage do not apply firmly
7. tell the person to keep the wound clean and dry. The dressing should be changed every two or three days
8. advice the person to seek medical help if the pain worsen there is swelling or redness the wound shows discharge, he feels unwell or fever
9. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. wash your hands before giving care
2. try not to come into contact with the persons stool or vomit. Use glove if available. Else you can use clean plastic bag to cover your hand
3. prevent dehydration by giving plenty of fluids to the sick person
4. children under two years should drink quarter and half of a large cup (50 – 100 ml) after each loose stool
5. children between two to ten years should drink half to full cups (100 – 200 ml) after each loose stool
6. children above ten years and adults should drink (200 ml) after each loose stool
7. advice the sick person to drink ORS (oral rehydration solution) which is available at chemist and government healthcare facilities
8. you may give the sick person curd or rice water if available
9. the sick person also may eat light food
10. check regularly on the sick person (during day and night) and sick medical help if the condition worsens

11. advice the person to seek immediate medical help if the diarrhoea does not get better within two days there is bloodin the stool: he has fever he is developing signs of dehydration (dry mouth, sunken eyes crying without tears)he can’t drink; he vomits frequently or he has fits
12. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Make sure the area is safe
2. Ensure the dog can’t bite you
3. Wash your hand is it possible
4. Try to avoid in coming contact with the person’s blood. Use glove if available or you can use clean plastic bag to cover your hand
5. Flush the bite wound immediately with clean water for 10 – 15 minutes. Wash the wound with water with detergent if available.
6. In case of bleeding stop the bleeding by putting direct pressure
7. Cover the wound with clean cotton cloth
8. Always refer the person healthcare centre for further treatment
9. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Make sure you are not in danger of drowning
2. Shout or call help
3. Try to throw a rope or something to the person which he can hold onto
4. Remove the victim out of the water but don’t put your self in danger by doing so
5. On rescued do not try to get the water out of the victim lungs
6. If the persons breaths put him in recovery position
7. If the persons do not breaths start giving CPR immediately
8. Always refer the person healthcare centre for further treatment
9. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Make sure the area is safe
2. Remove any object that could hurt the person
3. Reassure the bystander
4. Do not hold the person down or restrained
5. If possible, put something soft under the head
6. Make sure the person can breathe freely by loosening tight clothing
7. Do not put your finger in the person mouth
8. Do not put a wooden stick or anything else in the person mouth
9. Put the persons in recovery condition when the attack stop
10. Stay with the person until he stays in better condition
11. Do not give anything to eat and drink
12. Always refer the person healthcare centre for further treatment
13. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Make sure the area is safe
2. Put the person on the floor
3. In most case of fainting the person will recover quickly
4. Talk loudly to the person. Tap him on the shoulder
5. Check if the person responds to simple questions (what is your name, where do live)
6. If the person respond ask what happened. Allow the person to la down or sit in a comfortable position to recover. advice the person to recover.
7. If the person does not respond try to not to change the position of the person there might be injuries to the head, neck or back
8. The unconsciousness persons need urgent need so call to healthcare
9. Check if the person is breathing by listening looking and feeling
10. If the person not breathing start CPR. If his breathing put him in recovery position keep observing him and arrange urgent transport to healthcare
11. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. wash your hands before giving care
2. find out how high is the temperature of the person is by measuring it or by feeling
3. ask the person to rest
4. move the person to cool environment
5. give the person a lot of water to drink to prevent dehydration
6. evaluate how the person is dressed. Too much can increase the temperature; to less can cause shivering
7. eventually you can sponge the sick person with room temperature water, except if does not like it or starts shivering
8. keep checking on the patient during day and night time
9. bring the sick person to nearby healthcare facilities if fever remain or the person condition worsen
10. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Make sure the area is safe
2. Shout or call help
3. Try to avoid to come in contact with the person blood. If you have glove you can putthem on. Else you can use clean plastic bag to cover your hand
4. Reassure the causality
5. Advise the person to stay calm and not to move
6. Try to not move the fractured or disorder limb
7. Try to not move the causality till the injured part has been secured
8. If there is bleeding, stop the bleeding by putting direct pressure on the wound
9. Cover the wound after the clean cotton cloth
10. Suggest the causality to support the injured part (broken arm) himself, ask a bystander to do so
11. Immobiliser the injured part with a bandage try not to move the injured part whilst doing so
12. If you are trend in h0w to splint, you can immobilize the fractured limb with a splint
13. Do not give the person anything to drink or eat
14. Arrange appropriate transport nearby hospital
1. Make sure the area is safe
2. Shout or call help
3. Remove any cause of suffocation but do not put your self in to danger doing so
4. Check if the person is breathing by looking listening and feeling
5. If he is not breathing turn or put the person on his back on the floor. Kneel down by the side of the person and start CPR
6. Continue to give CPR till the person starts breathing; trained help arrive and takes over; you become too exhausted to continue or the area become unsafe to continue.
7. If the person starts breathing again provide first aid (stop bleeding) keep him warm arranging urgent transport to healthcare if he stops breathing start CPR.
8. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Ask the person to pinch his nose above the nostril with his index finger and thumb. Tell him to breath through the mouth. Ask him to lean forward
2. If they cannot pinch himself. You can pinch the nose use glove or plastic bag to cover your hand
3. Continue pinch for 10 to 15 minutes normally the nosebleed will stop

4. Is there is still blood coming after 20 minutes or the bleeding was caused by a punch to the nose or head; or by fall or accident if the bleeding is heavy the person takes blood thinning medication or the person become pale,sleepy or unconscious; seek urgent medical help
5. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. First secure your own safety only thereafter, secure the safety of affected person
2. Shout or call help
3. Cover your hand use glove or plastic bag
4. If possible, find out what poison has been swallowed,injected, inhaled or came into contact with the person’s skin. However, do not put yourself in to any danger. Avoid contact with the poison.

5. Call the anti-poison centre or nearby hospital, healthcare centre or medical caregiver for advice. Do not give anything to eat or drink without their advice. Do not give milk or water unless they ask you to do so.
6. If the poison is swallowed and the person is conscious and breathing.Ask him to lay down on his left side keep on observing him.
7. In the case of external contact with dry chemicals or powder, brush them away and then rinse with water.
8. Arrange appropriate transport nearby hospital
9. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Make sure the area is safe

2. If you are in the area where the wasp’s hornet or bees are around walk with the victim calmly away to a safer area. If attacked by swarm, run away as a fast as possible and seek shelter (indoor, in a car)
3. Use your finger nail to remove the sting of the bee
4. Eventually wash the sting bite site with water
5. Do not try to suck out the venom. Do not put herbs on the wound
6.If you have ice available you may use it to cool; wrap the ice in a cloth so the ice does not touch the skin directly do not apply longer than 20 minutes
7.Observe the person. Ask about their known allergies’ reaction. This can become quickly a life treating situation and immediately medical help is required
8. Always wash your hands after giving care
1. Ask the person to smile or show his teeth check if the mouth is crooked or drooping at one corner
2. Ask the person to lift both arms, check whether both arms move up the same or one is drooping or drifting
3. Ask the person what happened. Check if he can speak clearly or he has problem in finding his words
4. A stroke is very likely when the persons have issues with any of the above actions
5. Let the person sit upright, if not possible, put him in the very recovery position
6. Ask the person to stay calm
7. Do not give anything to eat or drink
8. Arrange appropriate transport nearby hospital
9. Always wash your hands after giving care
